Articles.Content:
Recently i\'ve been trying to get a ridiculous amount few satellites in a GPS looking network and then realized i didnt have anything in geosynchronous orbit. So no problem, mechjeb helped get me into a perfect geosynch...

Then i wanted to put more up and came to the realization that since that first object will never actually move (relative to the space center) that every time i would launch another it would end up right next to the first satellite.. Then i messed around with the mechjeb\'s \'edit path\' option but i would still end up with a perfect rendezvous being next to the first satellite.

So my question is, does anyone know how to change my launch phase so that i dont end up next to that first one but still be in geosynch? =P
You can put yourself into a lower orbit and wait until you are where you want to be. Then burn to geosynch.

You\'re going to have to do some math for this one.

You\'re going to have to decide how far apart in phase you want your satellites, and work out the orbit that puts you back at the Kerbin-Synchronized altitude that far ahead or behind your target.

Say you want three satellites at 120-degree intervals. It\'s actually easiest to do this if you bring all three satellites at once.

Get yourself into Kerbin-Synchronous orbit, at 2868.4 km altitude. Drop the first satellite.

Now you want to drop the next one 120 degrees behind. You\'ll want to be back where you are now in 4/3 * the Synchronous orbit period, or eight hours. Grabbing an orbit calculator and doing some quick calculations, that means an apoapsis altitude of 4335.6 km for a periapsis of 2868.4.

Burn to put your apoapsis at that distance, orbit once, then when you get back into the Synchronous orbit, circularize. The first satellite is now 120 degrees ahead of you. Drop the second satellite.

Burn to push your apoapsis out to 4335.6 km again. Go around again. Circularize again. Drop the third satellite. You now have three satellites at 120-degree intervals. For now, anyway.

GPS satellites aren\'t in geosynchronous orbits, by the way. They\'re also not evenly spaced along their orbits But that\'s a longer, different discussion.
thanks for the help, i figured it had something to do with different starting orbits and none circularized orbits, just wasnt positive.
